Ants in the Dormitories and
too many girls at the mixers
were among the problems con• sidered by the DSRC at its first
meeting last Tuesday evening.
Representative Tom Gleason,
chairman of the DSRC Dorm
Committee, reported that he had
received several complaints concerning ants in the dormitories
and of unpleasant smells from
nearby garbage cans.
Two other representatives also
reported having seen ants. Representative Tom Renahan testified to having seen "little tiny
things" in his room. "They're
little red things," added president Neal Grove.
On the social scene, DSRC social chairman Jeff Granitt reported that the council had already spent four hundred dollars on its mixer program
and
was planning to spend over four
hundred more.
Granitt reported that the
number of girls expected at
this
Saturday's mixer, open to freshmen only, would probably
outnumber the boys. A freshman
who was present at the meeting
confirmed this, stating that
many of the freshmen he had
spoken with "would prefer to
study."
